comments.commentBody: Terrific puzzle  --  until I started thinking about my ex-.

Other, similar stories over the decades:
http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960320&sl...

http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20000903&sl...

Despite the Great Recession, despite millions of foreclosures, despite the very real inability of current generations to mimic the post World War II "Greatest Generation" achievements, i.e. gas pipelines, hydroelectric projects, schools, colleges, interstate-state-local highway systems, water projects, environmental cleanup... neo-Conservatives have sold the decline of America as preferable so well that those of us who recognize them to be nearly pathologically self serving liars see in our decline the belief of their supporters that it must be right because "Liberals" oppose it.

Racist rancher Cliven Bundy's face down last week of federal and state law enforcement is symptomatic of irrational fear among a large minority of Americans; fear of minorities, fear government is fencing them in, fear government will disarm them, fear of non-Christians, fear of powerful women, fear of the rise of LGBT...

In short, millions of Americans are obsessed by fear.... And super rich Conservatives, like Sheldon Adelson and the Koch brothers, unfettered now by our Supreme Court, are pouring tens of millions of dollars into capturing that fear in votes they hope will enable them to capture government, Piketty not withstanding.

Yes, it's gotten very bad; they hope to make it much worse.
.

As a European immigrant, I was entranced by America when I first came here, 45 years ago. Now, as a retiree, I'm closeted in one of its most liberal enclaves (Berkeley, CA) looking out with horror at the majority of the country. It wouldn't take a lot to send me back to Europe. Oh, and BTW, I owned a business I started for 25 years.

Settlers have been trying to annihilate Palestinians since 1882. Read Benny Morris's book.

"For decades the Zionists tried to camouflage their real aspirations, for fear of angering the authorities and the Arabs. They were, however, certain of their aims and of the means needed to achieve them. Internal correspondence amongst the olim from the very beginning of the Zionist enterprise leaves little room for doubt.

Morris provides excerpts from three letters written in 1882 by these first arrivals:

• Ben-Yehuda, who settled in Jerusalem in September 1881, wrote in July 1882 to Peretz Smolenskin in Vienna: "The thing we must do now is to become as strong as we can, to conquer the country, covertly, bit by bit ... We will not set up committees so that the Arabs will know what we are after, we shall act like silent spies, we shall buy, buy, buy."

• In October 1882 Ben-Yehuda and Yehiel Michael Pines, who had arrived in Palestine in 1878, wrote to Rashi Pin, in Vilna: "We have made it a rule not to say too much, except to those ... we trust ... the goal is to revive our nation on its land ... if only we succeed in increasing our numbers here until we are the majority ... There are now only five hundred [thousand] Arabs, who are not very strong, and from whom we shall easily take away the country if only we do it through stratagems [and] without drawing upon us their hostility before we become the strong and populous ones."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Aliyah

We might not negotiate with terrorists, but Israel has no excuse not to.

After all. on several occasions Israel has elected terrorists as prime minister. It can't be disputed that Menachem Begin and Yitzhak Shamir were terrorists.

As for the late unlamented Ariel Sharon, by any fair definition he was a terrorist. In 1953, Sharon led a cross-border raid against the village of Qibya in Transjordan. Sixty-nine civilians were slaughtered, two-thirds of them women and children. The act was condemned by the U.S. State Department, the UN Security Council, and by Jewish communities worldwide. The State Department described the raid as "shocking."
Israel refuses to recognize the State of Palestine and some parties in the coalition government will never do so. Why then is it necessary for Hamas to recognize the State of Israel?

Israel gives the right to vote to all Israeli-Arabs. When the Palestinians demand the right to vote, as you predict, they will have to become citizens of Israel. After all, someone must be a citizen in order to vote in any country. Then, the entire Israel-Palestinian conflict will be solved because all the Palestinians will be Israeli-Arabs.
This too shall pass

I grew up in St. Louis. Downtown there are a series of monuments, buildings and libraries that were built in the first half of the 20th century, some before 1920.

I vaguely recall reading inscriptions on those buildings stating, something to the effect, the value of education to a democratic society.

In the 1st half of the 20th century, the progressive movement was just gaining some traction. The middle class was growing and middle class values were puncturing there way into some of the upper classes.

The Junky Rich, those addicted to greed, don't want to cut any bargains with any other corners of society.

But the sober rich, even back then, saw the limits to a society limited to extremes and so was working towards a compromise solution.

Their society was going from oligopoly/plutocracy to something more democratic. The only way to protect their position then was to cut a deals - so that we'd have a society that allowed for some to be rich, ... and to look more middle class (in their values and their baring) so that the newly empowered classes would see in the rich something of value and something of themselves and so not come at them with pitchforks, ... and was to invest in education so that newly empowered people's wouldn't themselves get steered onto rogue ideological rule as happened elsewhere.

Some of the rich are not addicts or cruel. Warren Buffet looks, acts and seems to have values that are all middle class. He seems sensible.

The addicts are the problem

To view where the moral ground intersects with the American experience of slavery (much in the news!), this short-form work describes the role of faith and prayer in African-American lives during that period, using their own words, songs, and folktales (very funny; p. 4 & 17). Without blame, it includes a brief look at the lives of the wealthy, the cultural attitudes of the times with meticulous research.

From the site, Internet Archives, see "A Portion of Fault:" A Sea Island Prayer After the Civil War: [https://archive.org/details/WaltsProof16a]

Basketball has a saying, "ball don't lie." Conservatives have finally met this truth, but will step up dirty play.

The media's false equivalency will repeat shouts of Marx, but where media is silent is more problematic. It is silent on the deepest, most profound ideal in Western Christian tradition, an ideal that shaped the progressive movements of secular society and lead to long sustained social growth in opportunity and income--the ideals of moral intelligence; ideals of right, wrong, and how both are addressed and justice is applied.

Weekly, this case is built in North Carolina; it was at the center of the Occupy movement, and is a mainstay of Obama's social policies. It is heavily ridiculed, but even Romney wrestled with it. Its absence is being exposed as the GOP insists in putting balance sheets before good works.

In South Carolina, 101 children died in the care of the state's DSS in 2012; yet governor Nikki Haley opposes the Medicaid expansion in a state at the bottom of the national health matrix. Moral intelligence looks at what we do for others, what legacy we leave. It's time to look past budgets, the constitution, the ugly labels, the rising murders and madness, and point to the moral failings of a party that closed the very government the founders fought to establish; that passed laws to allow guns in church or to take the lives of neighbors and to say none of these were the original intent of the founders--and neither were special privileges for the rich.
I agree, it sounds like the only rule infraction was he was so blatant - but wink, wink - just don't be so obviously and it's ok.  That is what we always told Pete about those darn betting slips
Lots of players use it but it is discreet  . . . so ignored or not found. This was dumb
I'm no authority on cheating and I certainly don't condone it.  But isn't getting away with it the whole point of cheating?
So Pineda should have tried to (discreetly)  get away with it?

'And the Piketty panic shows that the right has run out of ideas.'

Yes and no, because the right has long since stopped looking for ideas anyway. It searches instead for slogans to fool people into believing the facts of hardening inequality either don't exist or must not be examined because scrutinizing them can only end in 'class warfare' (one of the right's prized slogans) that would propel us, supposedly, into a Gulag state.

On Wisconsin,
There have been many derogatory terms and code words used, but amateur is the nicest possible term to describe the mess of US foreign policy. I had high hopes for Obama and he has disappointed in nearly every realm.

You can dismiss my criticism as race based- but it is not. Instead, you might do better to accept that there is legitimate cause for criticism based upon results. I am sorry, but saying the White House run by amateurs is not a code word for anything other than incompetents --and that is judging by results, not skin color.

AK
While the mess at home is often referred to as inherited from Bush, it wasn't quite as bad as the foreign policy mess. Especially unpalatable were our roles in dragging allies into war, crashng global economic systems, and giving the NSA unbridled power.

We have not been nearly so much of a foolish gunslinging hegemon as we were under W. In fact, our repeated attempts at diplomacy will benefit us longterm.

I can't tell from here if the drone program is effective or not, but sanctions have worked in Iran and Syria, and they are starting to be effective in Russia. It's not that President Obama isn't countering the "chess" moves of adversaries, he just doesn't point out his play.

If anything, Obama has hardly been a dissappointment, but he has been lackluster.  He lacks the fortitude to take on his critics harshly, something he should have gotten over after his 3rd year in office.  These trade deals are often starting points and since congress is more concerned about getting re-elected that moving this country forward in any way, is really the cause of your disappointment.  Obama needed to take this trip to Asia if anything just to remind China of who really is the boss or more importantly, who people in that region would prefer to be the boss.  Any hopes or delusions you had, remember this is politics!!

Obama doesn't get it.  Know what you want and how you will accomplish it before you start the process.  And if your swinging for the fences be able to reach them.  Afghans are not listening, Israel isn't listening, Syria is listening, the Democrats aren't listening and neither are the Russians.  The White House is run by a bunch of amateurs.  And if none of these things get done, the world will not care.  It won't make a hill of beans difference.  Two and a half years and the circus is leaving town.
Finally the NY Times is forced to publish comments like yours. Half their readership realizes what a mistake they made when they voted for Obama.
And how many republicans, muckraker, can see the gross debacle that was GWB?

Obama, Kerry what foreign policy jokes! Makes me almost think Hillary could do a better job. Then the 3 o'clock phone call rings: "Hello, this is Benghazi/Damascus/Ukraine we are under attack." Yes, what difference does any of it make except their incompetence brings us closer to WW III?

Same old, same old.  In exchange for security concerns, economic issues are put on the backburner.  It's happened consistently since WWII.  During that period, the U.S. has lost millions of good-paying jobs and is now deeply, deeply indebted to the rest of the world.  Our priorities are backwards.  Where's the change that we can believe in?
Seems that Obama is incapable of anything except domestic spying.

The trolls are out today. Acknowledge the abject failures of a Republican dominated Congress to govern, and the criminality and incompetence of the Bush administrations. Who actually did take us to war, based on lies and vanity.
You are obviously confused.  It is Republicans who start wars.  It is Democrats who end them and try to get themm paid for.  Look it up.

Foreign policy has turned out to be too much of a whirligig for Obama. Time for him to get off. Unfortunately he has two more years to go before the ride is over. Let' s hope the price of the ticket is not another world war.

Do you think there aren't as many Russian young people who also yearn for opportunity, freedom of expression, and democracy? The reactive, cold war-inspired US policy is making sure that the Russian opposition is driven to extinction.

This conflict is not really about a choice between democracy and totalitarianism. It is about economy. Eastern Ukraine needs Russia because that is their market. It will collapse if its industries are forced to complete globally. It is also about nationalism. It is Greater Russia versus Greater Ukraine. Both countries have legitimate claims to Eastern Ukrainian territory. The borders didn't result from some elections. They were drawn by Bolsheviks. This is not even a new conflict. Western and Eastern Ukraine fought on opposite sides during the Russian Civil War and World War II.

"What is it about those French men?"

Unlikely anything to do with French men. It is called viewing a situation objectively as a curious - and usually sympathetic - outsider.

What is it about those French men?  First Alexis deTocqueville and now Thomas Piketty.  They describe American society so well.  Whenever I read a monograph about America's Early Republic I like to see how many paragraphs in before the author inserts a quote from "Democracy in America."  That visitor from France had a keen eye for what the country was all about.  Two hundred years from now when people read an historical analysis of the early 21st century, I believe they will see a quote from Piketty in the first few pages.  He, too, has us pegged.  Unless the oligarchs win, in which case all copies of his books will have long been turned to ash.

I truly feel sorrow for the Ukrainian people. With decades, if not hundreds of years of domination and abuse by the Russia or the Soviet Union, including thousands under the command of Stalin, Ukraine deserves better.
Alas, it is the Ukrainian's fight, perhaps with the support primarily of the EU nations. The US had little in this fight, except our revulsion for the self-serving and abusive way Russia treats a sovereign neighbor. It goes against American principles and ideals.
The American president is not doing nothing. He exercising measured, responsible behavior. Mr Obama's actions and Mr Kerry's worthy diplomacy are unlikely to dissuade Putin and Russia from doing what it chooses. But sanctions, as small as their affect is likely to be, does register our abhorrence about Russia's disgusting behavior.

All true and very annoying no doubt.  Too bad Ukraine never got on its feet, betrayed by its corrupt and incompetent leadership.  It can't end any other way.  A failed state with a divided population on the brink of civil war - would the outcome be any better if the Russians did nothing?  I doubt it.

The EU is so dependent on Russia that they cant even think of taking any action. Globalization is what it is. The US and the EU needs to refine their Russian policy after the latest debacle.  Especially with regards to their economic dependence on Russian gas and financial intertwining. Every country's sovereignty  has to be respected and Russia has to oblige. May be the think tanks in EU and United States change their foreign policy towards Russia. WW III is not an option. But some how the every country in the world needs to know there are consequences for Trespassing without an order.

Our interest is mainly our credibility with our friends. Obama's wonderful foreign policy have abandoned our friends and allies while emboldened our enemies. As one pundit said: our friends do not trust us, our enemies do not fear us.
More disaster on the horizon from this.

I'd like to know just what is the geo-political benefit to Russia, or more pointedly, the geo-politcal risk to US interests, by the Russian land grab of an impoverished land ( which, btw, is far away from us and right next to Russia) filled with angry people?

Stay out. Let 'em have it. If we truly believe that the long arc of history is toward democracy and capitalism then, eventually, Western interests will "win."

In the meantime, there's lots of suffering in the world which we could better focus our time, energy and resources on.

The West does not want to facilitate self-determination. It is all about getting a government that will vote to join the EU. The US is never interested in self-determination - it is interested in getting countries to support a US point of view or a US military presence on its soil.The US is NOT altruistic in its foreign policy.
James, I am saying that Americans should not care about Ukraine.
